answers.answer: I am thrilled that your eyesight is better....I am rather... Uh... Surprised you are not on any meds? The pituitary is a funny beast. It gets.... Antsy when whacked about and can be unpredictable at this point hence why the norm is to have you take at least hydrocortisone for the time being. It keeps you alive should your pituitary decide to get wonky (and it can happen fast) and you end up.... Very sick to maybe dead.Pain post op is usually pretty minimal. Just don't be bending over, using straws of going crazy, the lack of pain can sometimes lull people into thinking that hey, all this is okay and they do things they should not.  Do be careful.What is the endo saying?

question: Hi Everyone,Just 4 days post transsphenoidal resection.  It was benign and non- functioning.  The surgery was 2 hours, no packing and felt great in post op. The ICU afterward had its trials and tribe .  But, I think that was mainly due to my never having surgery prior to and being extremely anxious. It was all a bit overwhelming.  Going half blind, being diagnosed with a (close) brain tumor and needing surgery is mind blowing.  Pardon the pun.  My vision came back up 20/40 and 20/20.  The 20/40 was 20/200 prior to surgery and getting worse by the day.  So, this is just amazing.  I am home and resting comfortably. No diabetes, no bruising, stuffy nose that seems to fill and release like barometric pressure.  I didn't even need pain meds.  Tylenol, regular Tylenol on day 2..All good!  Need no medicines to come home with either..Things can go well if you get a good surgeon as suggested on this site.  My issue now is healing time, patience and reducing anxiety concerning CSF leaks.  Anyone have any data on how often this occurs and how long it takes before you needn't be concerned about it happening?Or, if there are any ways to help avoid this?  I am sure stressing doesn't help pressure in the head..
